The Johns Hopkins University has recently received
a $750,000 grant from the Ford Foundation to establish a
Department of Social Relations.
President Milton S. Eisenhower, announced this week
that the grant will provide for the appointment of two
senior and two junior faculty members. Graduate fellowships and other related expenses will also be paid by the
grant.

This is fine, but it is about the extent of their efforts. The

schedule, and that assembly is hardly a feather in their

The Case of V.V.L.
Let us suppose that Victor Vincent Liberabit possesses
an incredibly inept memory and atrocious reading comprehension. Since he assimilates knowledge slowly he is
constantly seen assiduously attacking one volume on reserve. Consequently he roams to and fro, from reserve
desk to home and back, toting the volume in his red
leatherette attache case, signing it out, not completing the
assignment, signing it out once more.
For argument's sake let' us further suppose that the
day finally arrives when Victor V. finishes his assignment.
He places the book in the desk drawer, falls fast asleep
dreaming of the truth which will set him free, and the
following morning, full of 'joie de vivre,' Victor merrily
carries his little red ,leatherette empty attache case to
school. The forgotten volume of lore sits; Victor's classmates stew; the librarian frets;' the Honor Commission
acts.
Our setting: a room in Gilman Hall. Around the oak
desk, lounged in leathered chairs, sit the members of the
r-Honor Commission. Victor Vincent cringes in some corner. A Commission member remarks that "Mr. Liberabit
was here once before because he 'forgot' to return a reserve
book, and was convicted."
"Why did you not return your reserve book, Victor
Vincent?". asks a Commission member.
"I forgot," answers Victor V. "I possess an incredibly
inept memory, atrocious reading comprehension, and am
constantly seen assiduously attacking one volume on reserve."
"We don't believe you, Victor Vincent. It is rather
hard to forget after once being punished, isn't it?"
"I forgot."
"We don't believe you," says an Honor Commission
man. "No man could 'forget' twice." The bodies in the
leathered chairs sway in agreement. Victor V. is led from
the room. A vote is taken. The Verdict is guilty, the
penalty, expulsion.
Victor Vincent Liberabit leaves the room. His red
leatherette attache case bumps and drags down the stairs.
"I forgot," says Victor V.
And he did.

Gather round, girls. Flip open a pack of Marlboros,
light up, enjoy that fine flavor, that good filter, relax and
listen while Old Dad tells you about the latest campus
fashions.
The key word this year is casual. Be casual. Be slapdash. Be rakish. Improvise. Invent your own ensembles
—like ski pants with a peek-a-boo blouse, like pajama
bottoms with an ermine stole, like a hockey sweater with
a dirndl.
(Dirndl, incidentally, is one of the truly fascinating
words in the English language. The word originated on
June 27, 1846, when Dusty Sigafoos, the famous scout
and Indian fighter, went into the Golden Nugget Saloon
in Cheyenne,Wyoming,to see Lily Langtry.Miss Langtry
did her dance in pink tights. Dusty had never seen anything like that in his life and he was much impressed.
He thought about her all the way home. When he got

skirt she had made for herself. "How do you like my new
skirt, Dusty?" asked Feldspar. He looked at the large,
voluminous 'garment, then thought of the pink tights on
Lily Langtry. "Your skirt is darn dull," said Dusty.
"Darn dull" was later shortened to dirndl, which is how
dirndls got their name.)
But I digress. We were smoking a Marlboro and
talking about the latest campus styles. Casual, we agree,
is the key word. But casual need not mean drab. Liven
up your outfits with a touch of glamor. Even the lowly
dungaree and :man-shirt combination can be made exciting if you'll adorn it with a simple necklace of 120
matched diamonds. With Bermuda shorts, wear kneecymbals. Be guided by the famous poet, Cosmo Sigafoos
(whose- cousin Dusty invented the dirndl), who wrote:
Sparkle, my beauty, .
Shimmer and shine, "
The night is young,
The air's like wine,
Cling to a leaf, .
Hang on a vine,
Crawl on your belly,
It's time todine.

is terribly important because no matter how good

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCT. 18, 1957

Correspondence
To the Editors:
Somewhere in the tumultuous
course of Hopkins history, a skill,
an ideal, a once-sacred tradition, has sunk into obscurity—
the fine art of sleeping in class.
How do the misguided youth
of today face the problem? Head
thrown back, limbs extended,
and mouth agape, they snore
blatantly somewhere in the rear
of one of the Remsen Hall
arenas. Or else they hit an
aesthetic rock bottom by simply
cutting the class in question and
sleeping in their rooms at the
dorm.
Gentlemen of the Hopkins,
let's approach the problem intelligently; let's apply to it the
same talents we expend in gliding
frisbees.
First of all: a convincing
camouflage. One hand should
clutch our pencil or pen and
should be moved, as if writing, at
intervals. This skill—sleeping
comforts—ably yet keeping in
hand in occasional motion—may
be hard to acquire; but it is
fully worth all effort.
The other hand should suppoft the head, with elbow on
desk top as a base, and almost
completely cover the eyes. As far
as the rest of the world is con-

cerned, you will be studiously
weighing the lecturer's every
word and efficiently taking down
everything he is saying—even the
jokes.
Equally difficult to master, but
equally necessary, is the somnolent position one assumes. Sit
relatively straight in your chair,
with head forward over desk as
described above. By no means
allow head or arms to lean in
any way—and don't forget to
give that pencil an occasional
push.
As the final stratagem, you
must remember to assume at all
times the careful posture I have
taken such pains to promote.
Awake or otherwise, maintain
this position and soon students
and instructors alike will think it
your normal mode of listening to
lectures. They'll realize that John
Smith always keeps his head
propped on his arm in class.
Victory!
The merits of this system of
attending class are too obvious
to require exposition. And remember, though you may be
missing a lecture, you are learning skills and talents which will
aid you any time, any place in
your future life.
—William Plantagenet.

Sports Editor

When will the Johns Hopkins student body consider
the football team worthy of its support?
It is a well known fact around the Hopkins that there
is only one athletic team that plays for full stands at Homewood Field. It is almost equally well known that lacrosse
receives the most promotion from the athletic department,
the school publications, and the scholarship committee.
We of the News-Letter are only able to rectify the
lack of emphasis given to other sports by the News-Letter
itself.
Students Have Power
The greatest power lies with the student body which
has the power to back or forget the other teams representing the school when the teams are most aware of it—on
the athletic field.
When asked if they felt that student support makes
any difference, two members of the varsity football squad
replied:
Frenda Speaks
"Does it make any difference? Sure, it does! A
great percentage of any sport is spirit caused by desire.
Fans give a player drive—the desire to win. One of the
toughest aspects in football at Hopkins is getting desire
or spirit from something other than a fan. "Fans"
around here mock the team. It's tougher to play football
at Hopkins than it is to play big-time ball. There are
times when I think the sport should be dropped because
it is entirely too demanding."—junior letterman guard
Frank Frenda.
"At Hopkins, a fellow plays football because he wants
to, not because he gets paid for it. The support of the
fans is about the only reward that a player gets for a job
well done. When the team is on enemy gridirons, support
of the team is of primary importance in bolstering the team
to victory."—sophomore fullback Rod Simonsen.
World of Difference
In reference to the Haverford game, Coach Wilson
Fewster said, "If we have three or four hundred up there
from Hopkins it'll make a world of difference. The
stadium is right on the field."
Directions to Haverford are as follows: Take route 1
pass Swarthmore to bypass 1, to 320, to Lansdowne Road
to College Avenue, which leads directly into Haverford
College.
Those driving should leave by 11:00 am., in order
to arrive by gametime at 2:15 pm.

"In a big company,a young man
can get to tackle big jobs"
"The thing that has impressed me most in my two
years at General Electric," says 28-year-old Yusuf A.
Yoler, manager of Aerodynamics Laboratory Investigations, "is the challenging opportunity open to
young people here. My field is guided-missile research
— the nation's top-priority defense job. Because of
the scope of the company's research and development
program,I've had the opportunity to work with technical experts in many related fields. And I've seen
at first hand the responsibility which General Electric
has given to younger men — proof to me that in a
big company a young man can get to tackle big jobs."
V

302 N. Charles Street
Importers of Clothing and
Furnishings Since 1898

The research being done by Dr. Yusuf A. Yoler is
significant not only to himself, but to General Electric
and the security of the nation as well. At present, the
company is participating as a prime contractor on
three of the four long-range ballistic missiles pro-

gramed by the U. S. government. Yoler, who is playing an important role in this work, directed the design
and development of the world's largest hypersonic
shock tunnel — a device which will "test-fly" missile
nose cones at speeds over 15,000 mph.
Progress in research and development — as well as
in every other field of endeavor—depends on how well
young minds meet the challenge of self-development.
At General Electric there are more than 29,000 college graduates, each of whom is given the opportunity
to develop to his fullest abilities. In this way, we believe, everybody benefits — the individual, the company, and the country.

The Case of V.V.L.
Let us suppose that Victor Vincent Liberabit possesses
an incredibly inept memory and atrocious reading comprehension. Since he assimilates knowledge slowly he is
constantly seen assiduously attacking one volume on reserve. Consequently he roams to and fro, from reserve
desk to home and back, toting the volume in his red
leatherette attache case, signing it out, not completing the
assignment, signing it out once more.
For argument's sake let' us further suppose that the
day finally arrives when Victor V. finishes his assignment.
He places the book in the desk drawer, falls fast asleep
dreaming of the truth which will set him free, and the
following morning, full of 'joie de vivre,' Victor merrily
carries his little red ,leatherette empty attache case to
school. The forgotten volume of lore sits; Victor's classmates stew; the librarian frets;' the Honor Commission
acts.
Our setting: a room in Gilman Hall. Around the oak
desk, lounged in leathered chairs, sit the members of the
r-Honor Commission. Victor Vincent cringes in some corner. A Commission member remarks that "Mr. Liberabit
was here once before because he 'forgot' to return a reserve
book, and was convicted."
"Why did you not return your reserve book, Victor
Vincent?". asks a Commission member.
"I forgot," answers Victor V. "I possess an incredibly
inept memory, atrocious reading comprehension, and am
constantly seen assiduously attacking one volume on reserve."
"We don't believe you, Victor Vincent. It is rather
hard to forget after once being punished, isn't it?"
"I forgot."
"We don't believe you," says an Honor Commission
man. "No man could 'forget' twice." The bodies in the
leathered chairs sway in agreement. Victor V. is led from
the room. A vote is taken. The Verdict is guilty, the
penalty, expulsion.
Victor Vincent Liberabit leaves the room. His red
leatherette attache case bumps and drags down the stairs.
"I forgot," says Victor V.
And he did.

WHAT EVERY YOUNG COED
SHOULD WEAR
•
Gather round, girls. Flip open a pack of Marlboros,
light up, enjoy that fine flavor, that good filter, relax and
listen while Old Dad tells you about the latest campus
fashions.
The key word this year is casual. Be casual. Be slapdash. Be rakish. Improvise. Invent your own ensembles
—like ski pants with a peek-a-boo blouse, like pajama
bottoms with an ermine stole, like a hockey sweater with
a dirndl.
(Dirndl, incidentally, is one of the truly fascinating
words in the English language. The word originated on
June 27, 1846, when Dusty Sigafoos, the famous scout
and Indian fighter, went into the Golden Nugget Saloon
in Cheyenne,Wyoming,to see Lily Langtry.Miss Langtry
did her dance in pink tights. Dusty had never seen anything like that in his life and he was much impressed.
He thought about her all the way home. When he got

home his wife Feldspar was waiting to show him a new
skirt she had made for herself. "How do you like my new
skirt, Dusty?" asked Feldspar. He looked at the large,
voluminous 'garment, then thought of the pink tights on
Lily Langtry. "Your skirt is darn dull," said Dusty.
"Darn dull" was later shortened to dirndl, which is how
dirndls got their name.)
But I digress. We were smoking a Marlboro and
talking about the latest campus styles. Casual, we agree,
is the key word. But casual need not mean drab. Liven
up your outfits with a touch of glamor. Even the lowly
dungaree and :man-shirt combination can be made exciting if you'll adorn it with a simple necklace of 120
matched diamonds. With Bermuda shorts, wear kneecymbals. Be guided by the famous poet, Cosmo Sigafoos
(whose- cousin Dusty invented the dirndl), who wrote:
Sparkle, my beauty, .
Shimmer and shine, "
The night is young,
The air's like wine,
Cling to a leaf, .
Hang on a vine,
Crawl on your belly,
It's time todine.
(Mr. Sigafoos, it should be explained, was writing
about a glowworm. Insects, as everyone knows are

his Tumbling Along with the Tumbling Tumblebug? Or

Memorial" for squatty heads; "Niagara Falls" for dry
scalps. Feature of the collection is the "Statue of
Liberty," complete with a torch that actually burns.

is terribly important because no matter how good

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCT. 18, 1957

Correspondence
To the Editors:
Somewhere in the tumultuous
course of Hopkins history, a skill,
an ideal, a once-sacred tradition, has sunk into obscurity—
the fine art of sleeping in class.
How do the misguided youth
of today face the problem? Head
thrown back, limbs extended,
and mouth agape, they snore
blatantly somewhere in the rear
of one of the Remsen Hall
arenas. Or else they hit an
aesthetic rock bottom by simply
cutting the class in question and
sleeping in their rooms at the
dorm.
Gentlemen of the Hopkins,
let's approach the problem intelligently; let's apply to it the
same talents we expend in gliding
frisbees.
First of all: a convincing
camouflage. One hand should
clutch our pencil or pen and
should be moved, as if writing, at
intervals. This skill—sleeping
comforts—ably yet keeping in
hand in occasional motion—may
be hard to acquire; but it is
fully worth all effort.
The other hand should suppoft the head, with elbow on
desk top as a base, and almost
completely cover the eyes. As far
as the rest of the world is con-

cerned, you will be studiously
weighing the lecturer's every
word and efficiently taking down
everything he is saying—even the
jokes.
Equally difficult to master, but
equally necessary, is the somnolent position one assumes. Sit
relatively straight in your chair,
with head forward over desk as
described above. By no means
allow head or arms to lean in
any way—and don't forget to
give that pencil an occasional
push.
As the final stratagem, you
must remember to assume at all
times the careful posture I have
taken such pains to promote.
Awake or otherwise, maintain
this position and soon students
and instructors alike will think it
your normal mode of listening to
lectures. They'll realize that John
Smith always keeps his head
propped on his arm in class.
Victory!
The merits of this system of
attending class are too obvious
to require exposition. And remember, though you may be
missing a lecture, you are learning skills and talents which will
aid you any time, any place in
your future life.
—William Plantagenet.

Sports Editor

When will the Johns Hopkins student body consider
the football team worthy of its support?
It is a well known fact around the Hopkins that there
is only one athletic team that plays for full stands at Homewood Field. It is almost equally well known that lacrosse
receives the most promotion from the athletic department,
the school publications, and the scholarship committee.
We of the News-Letter are only able to rectify the
lack of emphasis given to other sports by the News-Letter
itself.
Students Have Power
The greatest power lies with the student body which
has the power to back or forget the other teams representing the school when the teams are most aware of it—on
the athletic field.
When asked if they felt that student support makes
any difference, two members of the varsity football squad
replied:
Frenda Speaks
"Does it make any difference? Sure, it does! A
great percentage of any sport is spirit caused by desire.
Fans give a player drive—the desire to win. One of the
toughest aspects in football at Hopkins is getting desire
or spirit from something other than a fan. "Fans"
around here mock the team. It's tougher to play football
at Hopkins than it is to play big-time ball. There are
times when I think the sport should be dropped because
it is entirely too demanding."—junior letterman guard
Frank Frenda.
"At Hopkins, a fellow plays football because he wants
to, not because he gets paid for it. The support of the
fans is about the only reward that a player gets for a job
well done. When the team is on enemy gridirons, support
of the team is of primary importance in bolstering the team
to victory."—sophomore fullback Rod Simonsen.
World of Difference
In reference to the Haverford game, Coach Wilson
Fewster said, "If we have three or four hundred up there
from Hopkins it'll make a world of difference. The
stadium is right on the field."
Directions to Haverford are as follows: Take route 1
pass Swarthmore to bypass 1, to 320, to Lansdowne Road
to College Avenue, which leads directly into Haverford
College.
Those driving should leave by 11:00 am., in order
to arrive by gametime at 2:15 pm.

"In a big company,a young man
can get to tackle big jobs"
"The thing that has impressed me most in my two
years at General Electric," says 28-year-old Yusuf A.
Yoler, manager of Aerodynamics Laboratory Investigations, "is the challenging opportunity open to
young people here. My field is guided-missile research
— the nation's top-priority defense job. Because of
the scope of the company's research and development
program,I've had the opportunity to work with technical experts in many related fields. And I've seen
at first hand the responsibility which General Electric
has given to younger men — proof to me that in a
big company a young man can get to tackle big jobs."
V

302 N. Charles Street
Importers of Clothing and
Furnishings Since 1898

The research being done by Dr. Yusuf A. Yoler is
significant not only to himself, but to General Electric
and the security of the nation as well. At present, the
company is participating as a prime contractor on
three of the four long-range ballistic missiles pro-

gramed by the U. S. government. Yoler, who is playing an important role in this work, directed the design
and development of the world's largest hypersonic
shock tunnel — a device which will "test-fly" missile
nose cones at speeds over 15,000 mph.
Progress in research and development — as well as
in every other field of endeavor—depends on how well
young minds meet the challenge of self-development.
At General Electric there are more than 29,000 college graduates, each of whom is given the opportunity
to develop to his fullest abilities. In this way, we believe, everybody benefits — the individual, the company, and the country.
